descriptionSet.description: The Taj Mahal as well as the Yard in front of it can be seen as well as "Grahams Manchester" in Burmese, Assamese, Bengali and English scripts. Lush gardens to both sides of the water pond in which the Taj Mahal is reflected. A man stands at the side of the pond, as if posing for a photograph.

titleSet.title: Textile label depicting the Taj Mahal

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: Grahams - Manchester.
text-en: Taj Mahal Agra.
text-: ADD TEXT HERE
text-: ADD TEXT HERE
text-: ADD TEXT HERE
text-en: 1353.

description-en: The Taj Mahal as well as the Yard in front of it can be seen as well as "Grahams Manchester" in Burmese, Assamese, Bengali and English scripts. Lush gardens to both sides of the water pond in which the Taj Mahal is reflected. A man stands at the side of the pond, as if posing for a photograph.

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The variety of the Indian Scripts shows the popularity of the Taj Mahal in different Indian states. This popularity is the main reason why Grahams Manchester is using the motive of the Taj Mahal for its advertisements. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The Taj Mahal located in the Indian City of Agra (Uttar Pradesh) is seen as a symbol for the love between the Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan and his Wife Mumtaz Mahal. The Picture of the Taj Mahal is regularly seen as a decorative element in either Muslim or Hindu households. It has become a national icon. (Catherine B. Asher) (gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: It was contructed by the mughal emperor, Shah Jahan in memory of his wife, queen Mumtaz Mahal. The Taj Mahal has become a global symbol of love. (gs/cb)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: It features among seven wonders of the world and it is located at Agra, India. (AC)

related literature: Asher, Catherine B. 2010. Fantasizing the Mughals and Popular Perceptions of the Taj Mahal. Tasveer Ghar. http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/114/index.html, last accessed 2010-10-19 (gs)
related literature: Cyran, Eberhard (1993). Taj Mahal. Die Erinnerungen des Kaisers Sha Jahan." Heilbronn: Salzer. (gs)
related literature: Preston, Diana (2007). "A teardrop on the cheek of time. The story of the Taj Mahal". London: Doubleday. (gs)
related literature: Edensor, Tim. 2002. Tourists at the Taj. Performance and Meaning at a Symbolic Site. London/New York: Routledge
